Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Info Source: Included in a dataset downloaded at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Company is plan administrator. Penalty amount reported in range of $10,001 to $50,000.

Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: DaVita Healthcare Partners, Inc., the largest provider of dialysis services in the United States, agreed to pay $450 million to resolve claims that it violated the False Claims Act by knowingly creating unnecessary waste in administering the drugs Zemplar and Venofer to dialysis patients, and then billing the federal government for such avoidable waste.

DaVita Healthcare Partners, Inc., one of the leading providers of dialysis services in the United States, agreed to pay $350 million to resolve claims that it violated the False Claims Act by paying kickbacks to induce the referral of patients to its dialysis clinics.

Info Source: Included in a dataset downloaded at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Company is plan administrator. Penalty amount reported in range of $10,001 to $50,000.

Description: DaVita Rx LLC, a nationwide pharmacy that specializes in serving patients with severe kidney disease, agreed to pay a total of $63.7 million to resolve False Claims Act allegations relating to improper billing practices and unlawful financial inducements to federal healthcare program beneficiaries.

Company: Healthcare Partners Medical Group (now DaVita Medical Group)
Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Los Angeles
Private Litigation Case Title: EDNA RODRIGUEZ vs. HEALTHCARE PARTNERS MEDICAL GROUP INC
Bernal v. DaVita, Inc et al

Description: HealthCare Partners Holdings LLC, doing business as DaVita Medical Holdings LLC, agreed to pay $270 million to resolve its False Claims Act liability for providing inaccurate information that caused Medicare Advantage Plans to receive inflated Medicare payments.

DaVita Healthcare Partners agreed to pay more than $22 million to five states -- California, Colorado, Florida, Kentucky and Ohio -- to settle allegations that it paid illegal kickbacks to induce the referral of patients to its dialysis clinics, thereby causing false claims to be submitted to the states' Medicaid programs.

DaVita agreed to pay $3.2 million to settle multistate litigation alleging False Claims Act violations relating to improper billing practices and unlawful financial inducements to federal healthcare program beneficiaries. This was part of a larger $63.7 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-davita-rx-llc
DaVita agreed to pay $125,000 to the state in settlement of allegations its employees engaged in actions that may have qualified as soliciting insurance without the required licensing.

Agency: South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control

Company: DaVita Inc. and Total Renal Care, Inc.

Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php
